Award.AwardTitle: Workshop in Knot Concordance and Homology Cobordism
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 1957, R. H. Fox and J. Milnor introduced the seminal idea that the concordance class of the link of a singularity obstructs its removal. Both concordance of knots, and the motivating goal of understanding singularities remain central to topology and algebraic geometry. In the last 10 years we have seen tremendous advances in our knowledge of knot and link concordance. The introduction of the n-solvable filtration, by Cochran-Orr-Teichner, and the subsequent work of many authors establishing the non-triviality of (half of) the graded quotients has led to the realization that perhaps knot concordance is as fully complicated as the fundamental group might allow. A conference will be held at Wesleyan University, July 19-23, 2010, to bring together a variety of researchers and students whose work connects to knot concordance.

Knot theory is the study of knotted curves in 3-space. The study of knotted curves has important applications in biology and physics. A fundamental question in knot theory and low-dimensional topology is when such a curve bounds a disk in 4-space. This motivating question is the foundation for the study of knot concordance. Knot concordance was born of the study of 4-manifolds and remains its most accessible progeny.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A conference entitled "Knot Concordance and Homology Cobordism Workshop" was held at Wesleyan University July 19-23, 2010. In 1957, R. H. Fox and J. Milnor introduced the seminal idea that the concordance class of the link of a singularity obstructs its removal. Both concordance of knots, and the motivating goal of understanding singularities remain central to topology and algebraic geometry. The conference brought together a variety of researchers and students in geometric topology whose work connects to this fundamental idea. The participants included international experts in the field who are rarely able to have face-to-face discussions with each other about common research interests. Several participants have since produced joint papers together. The conference organizers especially encouraged the participation of graduate students and postdocs, almost all of whom gave talks during the conference. In fact, over half of the conference participants were graduate students or postdocs. Moreover, the conference participants included an unusually high percentage of women compared to most math conferences, with over a third of the participants being women. In addition to the support provided by the National Science Foundation, the conference was partially funded by the Mathematics and Computer Science Department of Wesleyan University via its Van Vleck fund.
